<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 217, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Maya is an athlete who competes in 1500-metre races. Last summer her practice run times had mean 4.22 minutes. Over the winter she has done some intense training to try to improve her times. A random sample of 10 of her practice run times, \(x\) minutes, this summer are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 133, 623, 152]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 42.05\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 176.83\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
Maya's new practice run times are normally distributed. She believes that on average her times have improved as a result of her training.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 751, 229]]<|/det|>
Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether Maya's belief is supported by the data.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|> A town council has published its plans for redeveloping the town centre and residents are being asked whether they approve or disapprove. A random sample of 250 responses has been selected from residents in the four main streets in the town: North, East, South and West Streets. The results are shown in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 148, 814, 227]]<|/det|>
North StreetEast StreetSouth StreetWest Street
Approve33544226
Disapprove1939289
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 238, 920, 273]]<|/det|> Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether the opinions of the residents are independent of the streets on which they live. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 255, 920, 273]]<|/det|> [7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 918, 135]]<|/det|> Scientists are studying the effects of exercise on LDL blood cholesterol levels. Over a three-month period, a large group of people exercised for 20 minutes each day. For a randomly chosen sample of 10 of these people, the LDL blood cholesterol levels were measured at the beginning and the end of the three-month period. The results, measured in suitable units, are as follows. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 144, 920, 225]]<|/det|>
PersonABCDEFGHIJ
Cholesterol levelBeginning72841209010213564758088
End64761059210511567757584
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 234, 144, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 234, 920, 268]]<|/det|> Test, at the \(2.5\%\) significance level, whether there is evidence that the population mean LDL blood cholesterol level has reduced by more than 2 units after the three-month period. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 249, 918, 268]]<|/det|> [7] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 280, 915, 300]]<|/det|>
...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 915, 338]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 358, 915, 376]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 915, 414]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 434, 915, 452]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 472, 915, 490]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 915, 528]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 915, 566]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 915, 604]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 624, 915, 641]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 661, 915, 678]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 698, 915, 715]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 735, 915, 752]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 772, 915, 789]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 866, 144, 884]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 866, 567, 884]]<|/det|> State any assumption that you have made in part **(a)**. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 866, 918, 884]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 905, 915, 922]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 932, 915, 950]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 948, 170, 963]]<|/det|> © UCLES 2023

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 87, 828, 228]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 247, 920, 267]]<|/det|>
As shown in the diagram, the continuous random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 268, 616, 339]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}mx & 0\leqslant x\leqslant 2,\\ \displaystyle \frac{k}{x^2} +c & 2\leqslant x\leqslant 6,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 363, 374]]<|/det|>
where \(m, k\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 144, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 384, 730, 405]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant 2) = \frac{1}{3}\), show that \(m = \frac{1}{6}\) and find the values of \(k\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 386, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 638, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the exact numerical value of the interquartile range of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 395, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
Kenny throws an ordinary fair 6-sided dice repeatedly. The random variable \(X\) is the number of throws that Kenny takes in order to obtain a 6. The random variable \(Z\) denotes the sum of two independent values of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 512, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the probability generating function of \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 168]]<|/det|> A school is conducting an experiment to see whether the distance that children can throw a ball increases in hot weather. On a cold day, all the children at the school were asked to throw a ball as far as possible. The distances thrown were measured and recorded. The median distance thrown by a random sample of 25 of the children was \(22.0\mathrm{m}\). The children were asked to throw the ball again on a hot day. The distances thrown by the same 25 children were measured and recorded and these distances, in m, are shown below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 178, 764, 260]]<|/det|>
21.223.522.918.619.4
22.126.520.225.720.6
22.317.422.227.023.9
28.222.627.223.023.7
19.822.723.321.524.3
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 272, 784, 291]]<|/det|> The teacher claims that on average the distances thrown will be further when it is hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 920, 336]]<|/det|> Carry out a Wilcoxon signed-rank test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, to test whether the data supports the teacher's claim. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 323, 920, 341]]<|/det|> [10]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
